history.content:
uGSIs used to only get salaries, not tuition paid. Then some rule got passed along the lines of "university workers at quarter time (10 hours) or more must get tuition paid." So tuition was paid.

Then the EE/CS department started going broke because of all the tuition they were paying, so 8 hour positions were created to circumvent this. But then people complained because that 2 hour difference per week would allow for tuition reimbursement. And yes, that is an almost negligible amount of work per week for tuition.

Now there are are no more 10 hour positions (in general?) to compare that against. But you still get pretty penny in wages.

children.subject:
Fee remissions for 25+% positions are in addition to being paid.

You can see the fee remission rules here: http://grad.berkeley.edu/financial/fee-remissions/, the fee schedule here: http://registrar.berkeley.edu/tuition-fees-residency/tuition-fees/fee-schedule, and the current GSI rates here: http://hr.berkeley.edu/labor/contracts/BX/current-rates (the number you are looking for is GSI I, which is the monthly pay for a full time-equivalent (i.e. 40 hour) GSI).

No, tuition is on top of salary. $4,010.10 <- monthly wage for 2016.

  • For x hours, $$x < 10:$$ $$(x/40) * 4,010.10$$
  • For x hours, $$x \geq 10: (x/40) * 4,010.10$$ plus fee remission (i.e. tuition reimbursement.)

Is the amount of tuition being paid equivalent to an hourly rate that's the same as 8 hour positions. So the question is, are they actually getting paid the same, except in tuition form?

For example:

8 hour TA - 775 a month

10 hour TA - 775/8*10 a month, but in tuition form

20 hours TA - 775/8*20 a month, but in tuition form

history.content: For most CS classes, do they only have GSI positions for 6-8 hours / wk and 20 hours/wk? 10 hours / wk GSI positions disappeared due to budget cuts?
history.subject: GSI hours
